['He made significant contributions to fields such as calculus, number theory, and physics', 'Development of calculus: Euler is considered one of the founders of calculus, and his work on the subject helped establish it as a rigorous mathematical discipline.', 'Introduction of the "e" constant: Euler was the first to use the constant "e" (approximately 2.718) in mathematical calculations, which is now known as "Euler\'s number."', 'Contributions to number theory: Euler made important contributions to the field of number theory, including the development of the theory of prime numbers and the introduction of the concept of modular arithmetic.', 'Work in physics: In addition to his work in mathematics, Euler also made significant contributions to the field of physics', 'Prolific output: Euler was incredibly prolific, publishing over 800 works during his lifetime', 'Member of the French Academy of Sciences: Euler was elected a member of the French Academy of Sciences in 1766, becoming the first non-French member of the academy.', 'Foreign associate of the Royal Society: In 1748, Euler was appointed a foreign associate of the Royal Society, one of the most prestigious scientific organizations in the world.', 'Knight of the Order of the Golden Fleece: Euler was awarded the Order of the Golden Fleece by the Duke of Holstein-Gottorp in 1760.', "Namesake of several mathematical concepts: Many mathematical concepts, such as the Euler angle, the Euler-Lagrange equation, and the Euler's identity, are named after Euler."]
